newsitem.title: USA: NHL-OILERS' CZERKAWSKI GETS NATURAL HAT TRICK AGAINST OLD TEAM.
newsitem.headline: NHL-OILERS' CZERKAWSKI GETS NATURAL HAT TRICK AGAINST OLD TEAM.

text.p: Former Bruin Mariusz Czerkawski recorded a natural hat trick -- the first of his career --- and Curtis Joseph posted his second shutout of the season as the Edmonton Oilers blanked slumping Boston 6-0 on Thursday.
Czerkawski, acquired from the Bruins last January in the deal that sent goaltender Bill Ranford to Boston, entered the game with two goals in his first 11 contests.
"Scoring a hat trick is a great feeling but another place you want to score is probably in the same city you played before and got traded from," Czerkawski said.
"It's always a little extra and a little special. That was a great win, 6-0, it couldn't be better than that. Tonight's my first hat trick, it's tough to complain."
Joseph made 25 saves for his seventh career shutout and second with the Oilers. It was Edmonton's first-ever shutout in Boston.

After Miroslav Satan gave the Oilers a 1-0 lead 4:34 into the contest, Czerkawski made it 2-0 less than three minutes later. He one-timed Todd Marchant's pass in the slot through goaltender Scott Bailey's pads.

Czerkawski's second goal of the game with 6:43 left in the second period extended Edmonton's lead to 3-0. Bailey made a pad save on Jason Arnott's shot from the left circle, but Czerkawski banged in the rebound from the right side.
Czerkawski completed his first career hat trick with 1:54 to play in the second, working a perfect give-and-go with Kelly Buchberger and making a one-timer from the slot.
Marchant added a shorthanded goal 47 seconds later for a 5-0 advantage.
Buchberger had three assists and Michel Petit added his first goal of the season for the Oilers, who won their first game on a season-high six-game road trip.
Bailey, making just his third start of the season with Ranford nursing a right knee injury, made 35 saves and fell to 0-3.
"It seemed to me like they just kept coming and coming," Bailey said. "I'm just happy they didn't get 12 because it was highly possible, they had enough opportunities."

In Buffalo, Mikael Renberg's goal midway through the third period snapped a tie and John LeClair sealed the victory with his second tally of the game as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Sabres 5-2.
LeClair, who had two goals and two assists, after a slow start coinciding with the absence of linemate Eric Lindros has four goals and three assists in his last two games.
Philadelphia's Ron Hextall allowed goals on two of the first three shots he faced, but rallied to turn aside the last 12 Buffalo attempts.

In Chicago, Brian Rolston and Jason Smith scored 65 seconds apart in a three-goal second period and rookie Mike Dunham made 35 saves as the New Jersey Devils got their season-high third straight win, 4-2 over the Blackhawks.
Dunham, who was making his first NHL start, became the first goaltender other than Martin Brodeur to win for the Devils in nearly a year.
Valeri Zelepukin and Dave Andreychuk scored the other goals for the Devils, who improved to 3-3 on the road and broke a five-game winless streak against Chicago.
Chris Chelios set up both goals for the Blackhawks, who had not lost to New Jersey since October 1992.
At Florida, four different players scored goals and Johan Garpenlov and Robert Svehla each had two assists to lift the Panthers to a 4-2 victory over the Washington Capitals.
The Panthers, who took the first nine shots of the game, improved to 9-1-4.
John Vanbiesbrouck recorded 24 saves to improve his record to 7-1-3. The Panthers have allowed a NHL-low 25 goals and have surrendered more than three in a game only once.

In Ottawa, Steve Duchesne and Daniel Alfredsson each had a goal and two assists and Damian Rhodes made 31 saves against his former team as the Senators snapped a four-game winless streak with a 6-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

Denny Lambert added a goal and an assist and Randy Cunneyworth and Denis Chasse each contributed two assists for the Senators, who remained unbeaten at home (3-0-3) and posted their first-ever win over Toronto in eight tries (1-6-1).

At Los Angeles, Vitali Yachmenev, Yanic Perreault and Ed Olczyk scored third-period goals and Byron Dafoe made 27 saves, helping the Kings stretch their unbeaten streak to six games with a 4-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.
Rob Blake also scored for the Kings, who improved to 3-0-3 in their last six games.
Darcy Tucker scored his first NHL goal for Montreal, which dropped to 1-6-1 on the road this season.
